text.p: The proposed $1.4 billion merger of JP Foodservice Inc and Rykoff-Sexton Inc announced Monday will be slightly accretive to 1997 earnings as well as accretive to 1998 earnings, the chairmen of both companies said.
"There will be no (earnings) dilution in this transaction; it will be slightly accretive for the rest of the year," JP chairman Jim Miller said in an interview with Reuters.
According to Zack's Investment Research, JP is expected by analysts to earn a consensus $1.23 per share in fiscal 1997 ending this month and $1.48 per share in fiscal 1998.
In fiscal 1996, JP earned $0.88 per share on revenue of $1.24 billion.
Miller and Rykoff chairman Mark Van Stekelenburg said the new company will continue to look for acqusitions to grow within the $140 billion U.S. food service industry.
The merged company, to be called JP Foodservice, would be the second largest food service company in the United States behind Sysco Corp, they said.
JP and Rykoff will hold four percent of the U.S. food service market, while Sysco's share is 10 percent, they said, noting that they expect further industry consolidation.
The executives said they begain negotiating the merger about two months ago.

Under the terms of the agreement announced before Monday's U.S. market open, JP and Rykoff will merge in a tax-free exchange of stock under which Rykoff holders will get 0.84 of a JP share for each Rykoff share.
The transaction also includes the assumption of $700 million in Rykoff debt.

In midday NYSE trade, JP shares were off 1-3/4 to 28-3/8, Rykoff shares climbed 3-1/2 to 23-1/8 in NYSE trade, easing from a year-high 23-3/8 reached earlier in the trading session. Sysco was unchanged at 37.
